questions.question: A 30 y/o woman sustains a stab wound in the neck that is located just above the cricoid cartilage but below the angle of the mandible. The injury is causing severe bleeding, and there is concern about the potential involvement of vital neck structures. Which neck zone is most relevant for assessing potential injury to major blood vessels and the trachea in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Zone II Explanation: The described injury location, between the cricoid cartilage and the angle of the mandible, corresponds to Zone II. Zones of Neck Injuries Zone of Neck Location Contents Features Zone I (Option A) Between the clavicles and the cricoid cartilage. Innominate vessels Origin of the common carotid artery Subclavian vessels and vertebral artery Brachial plexus Trachea Esophagus The apex of the lung Thoracic duct Difficult surgical exposure and access due to the clavicle and bony thoracic inlet structures. Zone II Between the cricoid cartilage and the angle of the mandible. Carotid and vertebral arteries Internal jugular veins Trachea Esophagus Largest zone Most commonly injured Relatively easy access for clinical examination and surgical exploration. Zone III (Option C) Between the angle of the mandible and the base of the skull Distal carotid and vertebral arteries Pharynx Less accessible to physical examination Difficult to explore surgically.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a large right-sided pneumothorax and decreased breath sounds requires an intercostal chest drain (ICD). What is the most appropriate insertion site for the ICD?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 5th intercostal space, anterior axillary line Explanation: 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line is the safest and most common site for chest drain insertion. It lies within the “triangle of safety,” minimizing the risk of injury to vital structures. Safe Insertion Site: Triangle of Safety Anterior to mid-axillary line Above nipple level Below and lateral to pectoralis major Typically at the 5th intercostal space. Technique: Local Anaesthesia: Adequate to include pleura. Dissection: Sharp dissection: Skin only. Blunt dissection: Use artery forceps through muscle layers, particularly the serratus anterior, creating a short tunnel to reduce air entry. Drain Direction: Pneumothorax/Haemothorax: Towards lung apex. Pleural Effusion/Empyema: Near lung base. Avoid Neurovascular Bundle: Pass drain over the upper edge of the lower rib. Stitches: Secure retaining stitch, but don’t obstruct the drain. Vertical mattress suture: For pneumothorax Post-Insertion: Connect to an underwater seal device (one-way valve). Verify with a chest radiograph. Suction Consideration: Suction is not always necessary and can worsen air leaks in fragile lungs or shift the mediastinum. Avoid clamping a bubbling drain unless necessary.

questions.question: A 25 y/o male is brought to the ED after an explosion at a construction site. He was close to the blast and submerged in water. He has severe abdominal pain, difficulty hearing, shortness of breath, unstable vitals, and ruptured tympanic membranes on examination. Which organ is most likely to have sustained injury due to the blast?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gastrointestinal tract Explanation: Underwater blasts cause more significant damage to the gastrointestinal tract due to the pressure impact on hollow organs, making it the most severely affected organ in this scenario. Blast Injury: Extent of Damage Greater damage compared to bullet injuries due to complex blast waves. Explosion pressure wave exceeds 1000 pounds per square inch, involving incident and reflected pressure. Factors Causing Damage High-pressure wave impact. Mechanical, chemical, and thermal injuries. Inhalation of toxic gases and smoke. Types of blast injuries: Air Blast Injuries Underwater Blast Injuries Most commonly injured: Tympanic membrane (ear) - Rupture and middle ear damage are common Tympanic membrane (ear) - More likely to occur when the head is submerged. Gastrointestinal tract - When the head is not submerged. Most severely injured: Lungs - Blast lung injury is a common cause of delayed mortality and can cause pulmonary contusion, air embolism, and other damage Gastrointestinal tract - Underwater blasts can cause more severe GI injuries due to pressure effects on hollow organs Lungs (Option A): While the lungs are commonly injured in air blast injuries, in the case of underwater blasts, the gastrointestinal tract is more severely affected due to the pressure effects on hollow organs. Limbs and Brain (Option B & D): While the limbs and brain can be affected in blast injuries, they are not the most severely injured organs in underwater blasts. Reference: Blast Injuries - PMC (nih.gov) Blast Injuries - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Explosives and Blast Injuries - Injuries; Poisoning - MSD Manual Professional Edition (msdmanuals.com) Human Injury Criteria for Underwater Blasts

questions.question: A 32 y/o male presents after a car accident with severe chest and abdominal pain. O/E there are decreased breath sounds on the left side and abdominal tenderness. Chest X-ray reveals bowel gas patterns in the left thoracic cavity. A nasogastric tube is placed, and its tip is seen in the thoracic cavity. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.A: Initiate conservative management and observe the patient.
options.C: Order a CT scan of the chest and abdomen for further evaluation.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Emergency laparotomy. Explanation: The presence of bowel gas patterns in the thoracic cavity and the nasogastric tube in the chest are clear indicators of diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of abdominal contents into the chest cavity. Emergency laparotomy is necessary to repair the diaphragm and reduce the risk of complications like strangulation. DIAPHRAGMATIC INJURIES Mechanism of Injury Penetrating Injury: Injuries below the fifth intercostal space suggest possible diaphragmatic injury and Blunt Injury: Typically caused by compressive forces to the torso, often resulting in large diaphragmatic ruptures with herniation of abdominal contents into the chest. Diagnosis Acute Phase: Diaphragmatic injuries can be easily missed; often diagnosed during surgery or when complications arise. Chest X-ray: May show a herniated stomach if a nasogastric tube is placed, especially in limited resource settings. Thoracoscopy/Laparoscopy(VATS): The most accurate diagnostic tools, with laparoscopy offering additional evaluation and the possibility of immediate repair. Complications Herniation of Abdominal Contents: Due to the pressure difference between the thorax (negative pressure) and abdomen (positive pressure). Strangulation: High mortality if herniated contents become strangulated, especially if discovered late. Treatment Operative Repair: Recommended for all diaphragmatic injuries. Approach: Penetrating injuries should be repaired via the abdomen and via the chest to rule out hollow viscus injuries. Initiate conservative management and observe the patient (Option A): Diaphragmatic injuries, especially with herniation of abdominal contents into the chest, require operative repair due to the risk of strangulation and other complications. Conservative management is not appropriate in this scenario. Order a CT scan of the chest and abdomen for further evaluation (Option C): Although a CT scan can provide additional information, the diagnosis of diaphragmatic rupture with herniation is already clear from the chest X-ray and nasogastric tube findings. Schedule an elective surgery (Option D): Elective surgery is not appropriate in the presence of acute diaphragmatic injury with herniation of abdominal contents. Immediate surgical intervention is required to prevent complications. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 377 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 411

questions.question: A 45 y/o male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He is tachypneic, has severe chest pain, and paradoxical chest wall movement is noted on physical examination. His oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. A chest X-ray shows multiple rib fractures on the left side. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Positive pressure ventilation and analgesics Explanation: The patient’s trauma history, followed by the examination findings points towards the diagnosis of a flail chest . Positive pressure ventilation is the appropriate initial management in such cases. Analgesics are significant for managing flail chest, along with Positive pressure ventilation. If the patient continues to deteriorate, Intubation and mechanical ventilation are used. Positive pressure ventilation helps to stabilize the flail segment by providing consistent internal pressure, reducing paradoxical movement, and improving oxygenation. Flail Chest: Occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places , creating a flail segment that moves independently. It exhibits paradoxical chest movement (inwards during inhalation & outwards during exhalation) Features: Hypoventilation: Reduced lung ventilation leads to low oxygen and high CO I levels. Mediastinal Flutter: Abnormal mediastinal movement risks sudden cardiac arrest. Pendular Air Movement: Inefficient air exchange between lungs. Complications : Hemothorax: Blood in the chest cavity. Pneumothorax: Air in the chest cavity. Treatment : Ventilation Support: Oxygen supplementation and Analgesics- Initial management IPPV is the preferred TOC. Tracheostomy if support exceeds 10 days. (Option A ruled out) Injury Management: Intercostal Tube Drainage : Removes air/fluids from the pleural space. Rib Fixation : Stabilises the chest wall. Supportive Care: Blood Transfusions : For blood loss. IV Fluids : For hydration. Antibiotics : To prevent infection. Medications : Bronchodilators and steroids. Thoracotomy: Considered in severe cases Intercostal tube drainage (Option B) is used for pneumothorax or hemothorax, which may accompany the flail chest. However, without these complications, immediate airway management and stabilization are more crucial given the severity of the respiratory distress. Thoracotomy (Option D) is reserved for massive hemothorax, persistent air leaks, or severe thoracic injuries that cannot be managed conservatively. It is not the initial treatment for flail chest with respiratory distress unless other severe complications are present. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 1100, 1101 Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 375

questions.question: A 45 y/o male is brought to the emergency room after a car accident with a penetrating injury to the left chest. An eFAST reveals fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac. Which of the following is not a component of Beck's triad, a classic finding in pericardial tamponade?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bradycardia Explanation: Bradycardia is not part of Beck's triad; in fact, patients with pericardial tamponade typically present with tachycardia as a compensatory response to hypotension. Pericardial Tamponade Pericardial tamponade is a life-threatening condition where blood accumulates in the non-distensible pericardial sac, leading to compression of the heart and obstruction of venous return. Aetiology: Penetrating trauma to the heart. Pathophysiology: Even a small amount of blood (as little as 50 mL) in the pericardial sac can increase pressure, decreasing cardiac chamber filling during diastole, and leading to obstructive shock. Clinical Features: Becks Triad Hypotension (Option A ruled out) : A key component of Beck's triad, indicating reduced cardiac output due to heart compression. Jugular venous distension (Option B ruled out) : Due to increased venous pressure from impaired venous return. Muffled heart sounds (Option D ruled out) : Caused by the fluid in the pericardial sac dampening the heart sounds. Other symptoms can be similar to those of tension pneumothorax, including cyanosis, tachycardia, and agitation. Diagnosis: eFAST : Fastest and most reliable diagnostic tool, showing fluid in the pericardial sac. Chest X-ray : May show an enlarged heart shadow. Management: Emergency surgical intervention - Eg. Subxiphoid window sternotomy, or left anterolateral thoracotomy, to evacuate the hematoma and repair the myocardium. Pericardiocentesis : Not recommended in cases of traumatic cardiac tamponade. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 374 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page 409

questions.question: A 45 y/o man presents to the ED after a fall from a height. He is in severe respiratory distress, with rapid breathing. An x-ray film was taken of the chest which revealed the following. His blood pressure is rapidly dropping. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this patient's condition?

options.B: Tracheal deviation towards the opposite side

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bilateral equal breath sounds Explanation: The patient’s clinical findings and the X-ray image confirm the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax on the right side. Breath sounds are usually absent on the affected side. Tension Pneumothorax A tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function. questions.question: A 45 y/o male presents with severe chest trauma following a motor vehicle accident. After inserting a chest tube, the initial drainage is 1600 ml of blood, and he continues to drain over 200 ml/hour for the next three hours despite stabilization efforts. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.A: Increase the suction on the chest tube
options.B: Administer intravenous fluids and continue observation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Perform an urgent thoracotomy Explanation: An urgent thoracotomy is indicated for initial tube drainage >1500 ml in blunt trauma or persistent drainage >200 ml/hour for 3 consecutive hours as seen in this patient. Indications for thoracotomy Initial tube thoracostomy drainage > 1000 ml in Penetrating trauma > 1500 ml in Blunt trauma Persistent tube thoracostomy drainage More than 200 ml/hour for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients (In clotted hemothorax- first the clot is liquified, then thoracotomy is performed) Caked Hemothorax despite bilateral chest tube insertion Tracheobronchial injuries (TBI) Injury to descending thoracic aorta or great vessel injuries Pericardial injuries. Cardiac herniation Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation Open pneumothorax Esophageal injuries Increase the suction on the chest tube (Option A): Suction adjustment won't address ongoing massive bleeding. Administer intravenous fluids and continue observation (Option B): Observation is inadequate given the significant ongoing blood loss. Insert a second chest tube (Option D): Not appropriate for controlling ongoing massive haemorrhage that requires surgical intervention. Reference: Thoracotomy indications Indications SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1102 SRB’s Surgical Operations, Page 205 Bailey and Love Short manual of surgery, 28th Edition, Page 987

questions.question: A 34 y/o male presents to the ER after a high-speed car collision. He complains of severe shortness of breath, and physical examination reveals absent breath sounds on the lower left side with a dull note on percussion. The chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) ICD (Intercostal Drain) insertion Explanation: The given clinical scenario and x-ray imaging point to a diagnosis of left hemothorax. ICD (Intercostal Drain) insertion is appropriate for draining blood or fluid in the pleural space, as indicated by the clinical and X-ray findings. Hemothorax It is the collection of blood in the pleural space, a potential space between the visceral and parietal pleura. The most common mechanism of trauma is a blunt or penetrating injury to intrathoracic or extrathoracic structures that results in bleeding into the thorax. The most common cause of massive hemothorax is torn intercostal vessels (Secondary to rib fracture) Clinical features Chest pain Dyspnea Tachypnea Dull notes on the percussion Absent breath sounds Diagnosis Needle aspiration of pleural fluid – shows blood Chest X-ray – To assess the presence and extent of

questions.question: A 55 y/o female was involved in a motor vehicle collision and now complains of severe anterior chest pain. O/E, she has point tenderness over the sternum and visible ecchymosis. What is the most likely associated injury that should be evaluated in a patient with a sternal fracture?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Myocardial contusion Explanation: Sternal fractures, especially those caused by high-impact trauma such as motor vehicle collisions, are often associated with other significant injuries due to the force required to cause the fracture. Myocardial contusion is a common and serious associated injury, given the proximity of the sternum to the heart. This makes it a critical condition to assess for in patients with sternal fractures. Sternal fractures: Causes: Blunt anterior chest trauma: RTAs, falls, and athletic injuries. Deceleration injuries: Significant in high-speed accidents. Sternal insufficiency fractures Stress fractures: Due to repetitive upper body use (e.g., weightlifting). Clinical Features: Pain: Anterior chest pain exacerbated by deep breathing and coughing. Tenderness and swelling: Point tenderness over the sternum, possible soft tissue swelling, ecchymosis, or deformity. Complications: May include pulmonary injuries (pneumothorax, hemothorax), myocardial contusion, rib fractures, and other thoracic injuries. Management Imaging: Chest X-ray (Lateral view) & CT Scan Treatment: Analgesia & physiotherapy Surgical intervention: Rarely required unless for significantly displaced fractures or associated severe injuries. While rib fractures (Option A ruled out) , pulmonary contusions (Option B ruled out) , and pneumothorax (Option D ruled out) are also possible, myocardial contusion is particularly concerning due to its potential impact on cardiac function and its association with blunt chest trauma. Reference: Sternal fractures Bailey and Love Short Practice of surgery, 28th edition, Page 400 Schwartz Textbook of Surgery, 11th edition, Page 1304

questions.question: A 67 y/o man collapses and requires cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) in the emergency department. After successful resuscitation, imaging reveals a rib fracture. Which rib is most commonly fractured during CPR?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 5th rib Explanation: The 5th rib is most commonly fractured during CPR due to its location in the middle of the ribcage where chest compressions are applied with significant force. Rib Fractures (Fx) Rib fractures can be traumatic or atraumatic. Most rib fractures are due to direct penetrating or blunt trauma to the chest. Fx of ribs 1-3: Occurs due to high-energy trauma. (Options A & B) Fx of ribs 4-10: Most common. Fx of ribs 11,12: Difficult, since they are very mobile. (Option D) Clinical features: Pain (Most common) On touching On taking deep breaths On sneezing or coughing. May get aggravated sometimes during certain activities of the upper limb (such as overhead activities, or during heavy pushing, pulling, or lifting) B rachial plexus or subclavian vessel injuries (1st-3rd rib fractures) L iver , kidney , and spleen traumatic injuries (10th-12th rib fractures) Management: Conservative management: Analgesics, rest and ice Surgery: Cases of severe displaced rib fractures and flail chest Reference: Rib fractures Rib fractures

questions.question: Match each description with the correct layer of the scalp: 1. Pericranium a) Richly vascularized 2. Aponeurosis b) Periosteum 3. Skin c) Danger zone 4. Connective Tissue d) Connects scalp muscles 5. Loose Areolar Connective Tissue e) Sebaceous glands
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-b, 2-d, 3-e, 4-a, 5-c Explanation: Layer Description Skin The outermost layer; contains hair follicles and sebaceous glands that produce sebum for lubrication and protection. Connective Tissue Dense layer with blood vessels, nerves, and fat; richly vascularized , leading to significant bleeding from injuries. Aponeurosis A tough fibrous layer (epicranial aponeurosis or galea aponeurotica); connects frontalis and occipitalis muscles for scalp movement. Loose Areolar Connective Tissue It allows mobility between the upper layers and the pericranium; it is considered a "danger zone" due to the potential for infection to spread via the emissary veins (from the scalp to the meninges). Pericranium The innermost layer; the periosteum of the skull bones; provides nourishment and protection to the skull. Reference: Scalp Anatomy: Structure, Nerve Supply, Arterial Supply (medscape.com) Anatomy, Head and Neck, Scalp Veins - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: In a patient with raised intracranial pressure (ICP) that remains elevated despite initial management, which of the following strategies is considered a second-tier therapy for refractory cases?

options.A: Elevate the head end of the bed to 30°.
options.B: Administer mannitol to maintain serum osmolality < 320 mOsm/kg.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Perform a decompressive craniectomy. Explanation: Decompressive craniectomy is categorized as a second-tier therapy for managing refractory elevated ICP, used when initial treatments fail to control the pressure. This surgical intervention involves removing part of the skull to allow the brain to expand and decrease ICP. Active Management of Raised Intracranial Pressure (ICP) Indications for Active Management: Initiate if ICP > 20–25 mmHg for more than 5 minutes. Goals of Treatment: Maintain ICP < 20 mmHg. Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP): Ensure CPP ≥ 60 mmHg. Management Strategies: Positioning : Elevate the head end of the bed to 30°: Promotes cerebral venous drainage and decreases ICP. (Option A ruled out) CSF Drainage : Ventriculostomy: Preferred method for draining cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to reduce ICP. Osmotherapy : Mannitol: Maintain serum osmolality < 320 mOsm/kg to draw fluid out of the brain. (Option B ruled out) 2.5% Saline: Hypertonic saline solution to reduce cerebral oedema. Glucocorticoids : Dexamethasone: Used in conditions with vasogenic oedema, such as brain tumours or brain abscesses. Avoid: Head injury, ischemic stroke, or hemorrhagic stroke as it may not be beneficial and can exacerbate some conditions. Hyperventilation : Therapeutic Hyperventilation: Used only for short periods to decrease CO I levels and reduce ICP. (Option D ruled out) ICP Monitoring : Ventriculostomy: Preferred for continuous monitoring and CSF drainage. Fiberoptic intraparenchymal ICP monitor: Alternative for monitoring, especially in cases with diffuse oedema or coagulopathy. Pressor Therapy : Medications: Phenylephrine, Dopamine, and Norepinephrine to increase mean arterial pressure and improve CPP. Second-Tier Therapies (for refractory elevated ICP) : Decompressive Craniectomy : Surgical removal of a portion of the skull to allow brain expansion and reduce ICP. High-Dose Barbiturate Therapy : Reduces neuronal metabolism and increases neuron longevity Reference: Raised ICP Management of Raised ICP Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 368 Schwartz Textbook of Surgery, 11th edition, Page 218

questions.question: A 35-year-old male in a high-speed crash presents with sudden loss of consciousness and remains comatose with neurological deficits, despite normal CT findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) Explanation: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is consistent with the clinical presentation of a coma and persistent neurological deficits despite normal CT findings. DAI is caused by rotational forces and is often not well-visualized on CT but can be detected on MRI, making it the most likely diagnosis in this scenario. Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) A form of primary brain injury caused by widespread damage to axons due to rotational acceleration and deceleration forces, often associated with high-energy trauma. Causes: Rotational forces: High-energy accidents involving rapid acceleration and deceleration (e.g., motor vehicle collisions). Trauma: Blunt force impacts that cause the brain to rotate within the skull. Clinical Features : Impaired arousal : Often presents as coma or reduced consciousness due to damage in critical brain areas (e.g., pontine reticular activating system, bilateral thalami). Neurological deficits: Poor neurological examination, despite the absence of obvious radiographic global brain injury. Irreversible consequences: DAI is often associated with severe and lasting neurological impairment. Investigations : CT scan: May show hemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem in severe cases. MRI: More sensitive than CT . It shows small haemorrhages and diffuse axonal injury, particularly in patients who fail to improve neurologically. Postmortem examination: Confirms the diagnosis with axonal disruption and formation of axon balls. Prognosis: Very poor due to high risk of severe disability or death due to extensive brain damage. Contusions (Option A) are localized brain injuries resulting from direct impacts, which typically show visible haemorrhages and bruising on CT. The scenario describes a lack of clear findings on CT, making contusion less likely. Subdural hematomas (Option B) are typically associated with venous bleeding and can be visible on CT, often presenting with a crescent-shaped haemorrhage. Epidural hematomas (Option D) typically present as a lens-shaped haemorrhage on CT, usually associated with a skull fracture and more acute changes in consciousness. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 368 Schwartz Textbook of Surgery, 11th edition, Page 1837

questions.question: A 60 y/o male suddenly experiences an intense headache, described as the worst headache of his life, followed by vomiting and photophobia. O/E he has neck stiffness and a dilated pupil on the right side. A CT scan reveals bleeding in the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Intracranial aneurysm Explanation: The clinical scenario described is highly indicative of a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH), which is characterized by the sudden onset of a severe headache, vomiting, photophobia, neck stiffness, and neurological signs such as a dilated pupil. The most common cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm , responsible for about 50% of cases. Subarachnoid Haemorrhage (SAH) Intracranial haemorrhage into the subarachnoid space, typically originating from the basal cisterns. It may occur spontaneously or following trauma (Trauma > Spontaneous) Causes of spontaneous SAH: Intracranial aneurysms: The most common cause Hypertension: Contributing to the formation and rupture of aneurysms. Arteriovenous (A-V) malformations Blood dyscrasias Anticoagulant drugs: Increasing the risk of bleeding. Brain tumours (malignant): Causing vessel erosion or rupture. Clinical Features: Sudden onset: Severe headache with vomiting. Raised intracranial pressure : Signs like photophobia and neck stiffness. Focal neurological deficits: Hemiplegia, dysphasia. Eye changes: Ptosis, dilated pupil, abnormal eye movements. Sudden loss of consciousness Rebleeding risk: Occurs in 40% of patients within 6-8 weeks, often fatal. Investigations: Imaging: CT scan: Primary imaging modality. Angiography: Carotid and vertebral angiogram to identify aneurysms or vascular malformations. Lumbar puncture: Performed to differentiate from meningitis ; done cautiously due to risk of coning. Management: Surgical interventions: Clipping or wrapping of aneurysm. Craniotomy: Followed by necessary procedures. Ligation of the common carotid artery: Risk of hemiplegia. Therapeutic embolization : To block abnormal blood vessels. Excision of vascular malformations. Reference: SRB’s Manual of surgery, 6th edition, Pages 1083,1084 Bailey and Love Short manual of surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 708-711

questions.question: A 45 y/o male presents to the ED after a head injury sustained in a motor vehicle accident. He briefly lost consciousness at the scene but was alert and oriented upon arrival. A few hours later, he becomes progressively drowsy, and his right pupil is dilated. A CT scan shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Epidural Hematoma (EDH) Explanation: EDH is classically associated with a transient loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval and then rapid neurological deterioration, as seen in this patient. The CT image shows a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion that is characteristic of EDH,

questions.question: A 20 y/o male footballer sustains a blow to the head during a match. He did not lose consciousness but appeared confused and had difficulty recalling events before the impact. O/E, he is slow to respond and exhibits slight incoordination while walking. It is determined that he has suffered a concussion. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding his management?

options.A: He should be allowed to return to play if he feels better after 15 minutes.
options.B: An immediate CT scan is required to rule out a cerebral contusion.
options.C: He should be monitored for second-impact syndrome if he returns to play prematurely.
options.D: A diagnosis of concussion is unlikely since there was no loss of consciousness.

questions.explanation: prematurely. Correct Answer: C) He should be monitored for second impact syndrome if he returns to play prematurely. Explanation: Second impact syndrome is a rare but serious condition that can occur if a person sustains a second head injury before fully recovering from a concussion. Therefore, it is crucial to monitor for this and advise the patient to avoid returning to play until asymptomatic . (Option A ruled out) Concussion and Cerebral Contusions: Aspect Details Concussion Defined as an alteration of consciousness due to a closed head injury, typically without imaging abnormalities. Confusion, amnesia, lethargy, distractibility, forgetfulness, slow interaction, emotional lability, gait disturbance, and incoordination. Loss of consciousness is not required for diagnosis. Cerebral Autoregulation: May be impaired, increasing vulnerability to repeat impacts. Second Impact Syndrome A rare but potentially fatal condition involving malignant brain swelling after a trivial repeat injury in someone with a recent concussion (fatal). Advisory: Individuals, especially athletes, should avoid returning to play until fully asymptomatic. Postconcussive Syndrome A set of long-term symptoms following a concussion. Somatic Symptoms: Headache, dizziness, hearing and vision disorders. Neurocognitive/Neuropsychological Symptoms: Difficulty with concentration and recall, insomnia, emotional lability, fatigue, depression, and personality changes. Cerebral Contusions Commonly occur where the brain contacts the skull (eg., inferior frontal lobes, temporal poles). Can occur distant from the impact site due to brain movement (coup-contrecoup injury). CT Appearance: Heterogeneous, due to mixed injured brain matter and blood. Management: Rarely require surgery but may be evacuated to reduce the mass effect. An immediate CT scan is required to rule out a cerebral contusion (Option B): While CT scans can be useful, they aren’t always necessary for concussions unless there are red flags like worsening neurological symptoms, focal deficits, or significant mechanism of injury. A diagnosis of concussion is unlikely since there was no loss of consciousness (Option D): A concussion can occur without any loss of consciousness. The presence of confusion, amnesia, and other symptoms like incoordination are key indicators of concussion.

questions.question: A 68 y/o male on warfarin therapy presents to the emergency department after a fall from a ladder. He is fully conscious with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15. He reports no loss of consciousness but is unable to recall events that happened before the fall. According to NICE guidelines, what is the most appropriate timing for a CT head scan in this patient?

options.D: No need for a CT scan; observation only

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) CT scan within 8 hours Explanation: According to NICE guidelines , a CT scan should be performed within 8 hours If the patient is older than 65, Has a coagulopathy (e.g., on warfarin therapy), Has experienced a dangerous mechanism of injury (such as a fall from a height), Has retrograde amnesia(inability to recall events before the amnesia-causing event) lasting more than 30 minutes. This patient meets multiple criteria, making a CT scan within 8 hours the appropriate management. Neurological Observation and NICE Guidelines for CT Head Imaging: Aspect Details Neurological Observation in TBI (Traumatic Brain Injury) Crucial for managing moderate to severe TBI. Key Assessments: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score and pupil responses. Note the extent of retrograde and anterograde amnesia. Initial: Half-hourly for 2 hours. Follow-up: Hourly for 4 hours, then every 2 hours. If Deterioration: Return to half-hourly and resume the original schedule. NICE Guidelines for CT Head Imaging in Adults CT within 1 Hour: (Option A ruled out) GCS < 13 at any time. GCS < 15 at 2 hours post-injury. Focal neurological deficit. Suspicion of open, depressed, or basal skull fracture. Multiple vomiting episodes. Post-traumatic seizure. CT within 8 Hours: Age > 65. Coagulopathy (e.g., aspirin, warfarin use). Dangerous mechanism of injury. Retrograde amnesia > 30 minutes. NICE Guidelines for CT Head Imaging in Children Immediate CT: Suspicion of non-accidental injury. First seizure. GCS < 14, or < 15 in children < 1 year old. Signs of skull base fracture. Focal neurological deficit. Bruising, swelling, or laceration > 5 cm in children < 1 year old. Additional Criteria (If Multiple Present): Loss of consciousness > 5 minutes. Abnormal drowsiness. ≥ 4 vomiting episodes. Dangerous mechanism of injury. Amnesia > 5 minutes. Additional Notes These lists are not exhaustive; clinical judgment should be used in deciding whether to order a CT scan. CT scan within 24 hours (Option C): There is no recommendation in the NICE guidelines for a CT scan within 24 hours. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 362, 363, 369 NICE guidelines for neurological observation

questions.question: A 32 y/o male presents to the emergency department after a high-impact motor vehicle accident. He complains of a severe headache, difficulty smelling, and clear fluid dripping from his nose. O/E, there is no external evidence of trauma, but the patient has a subconjunctival haemorrhage in the right eye. What is the most likely location of his skull fracture?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anterior cranial fossa Explanation: This is the most likely location of the fracture (Fx), given the patient's symptoms of anosmia (loss of smell), CSF rhinorrhea (clear fluid leaking from the nose), and subconjunctival haemorrhage . These are hallmark signs of an anterior cranial fossa fracture, which often involves the cribriform plate and can affect the olfactory and optic nerves. Cranial Fossa Fractures: Fracture locations: Anterior Cranial Fossa Middle Cranial Fossa (Option B ruled out) Posterior Cranial Fossa (Option C ruled out) About Fx of cribriform plate. Fx of maxillary, sphenoid, or other sinus cavities. Less common. Clinical features CSF rhinorrhea Subconjunctival hemorrhage. Cranial nerve damage leading to: Anosmia (CN I damage) Partial or complete blindness ( CN II or III damage) CSF otorrhea Epistaxis Cranial nerve damage leading to: Inward deviation of the eye (CN VI damage). Facial muscle weakness (CN VII damage). Hearing loss, vertigo (CN VIII damage). Boggy swelling at the nape of the neck. Cranial nerve damage leading to: Difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, and muscle weakness (CN XI, X. XI damage). Management: Conservative management: For fractures without significant intracranial injury or those near dural venous sinuses. Craniotomy and elevation: Surgical intervention to elevate depressed bone fragments and address underlying injuries. Occipital bone (Option D): Fractures of the occipital bone are usually associated with trauma to the back of the head and can lead to issues like visual disturbances or cervical spine injuries. The symptoms in this patient do not suggest an occipital bone fracture.

questions.question: A 25 y/o male presents to the emergency department after being struck on the head by a small, high-velocity object. He is conscious but reports a severe headache. A CT scan reveals a depressed skull fracture with evidence of intracranial air. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.B: Surgical exploration and elevation of the depressed fracture.
options.D: Application of a pressure dressing to the fracture site.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Surgical exploration and elevation of the depressed fracture Explanation: Depressed skull fractures involve the inward displacement of a bone fragment by at least the thickness of the skull. The recommended management for these is surgical exploration and elevation, particularly when intracranial air indicates a dural breach. Surgery helps to reduce the risk of infection, address neurological damage, and correct the deformity. Depressed Skull Fractures: Aspect Details Mechanism of Injury Typically caused by small objects impacting the skull at high velocity. Fracture Type Usually compound/open fractures. Associated Risks High incidence of infection Neurological deficits Late-onset epilepsy Management Require surgical exploration and elevation. Intracranial air (indicating a dural breach) necessitates surgery. Open fractures (e.g., involving air sinuses) are managed with surgical exploration and broad-spectrum antibiotics. fracture - Skull fracture - Wikipedia, https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Depressed-Skull-Fracture-in-a-Term-Newborn-Infant-Suneja- Prokhorov/f037b4882b53279c5fbcab45cbdde8e74cf145b9 (SU535A); https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/De pressed-Skull-Fracture-in-a-Term-Newborn-Infant-Suneja-Prokhorov/f037b4882b53279c5fbcab45cbdde8e74cf14 5b9 (SU535B)" data-tags="" height="259" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/f26oPjVTzk2Y2FgdZrUu1740110540.png" width="500" /> Conservative management with observation (Option A): This is not appropriate for a depressed skull fracture, especially with intracranial air. Intravenous antibiotics without surgery (Option C): Intravenous antibiotics alone are insufficient; surgical intervention is necessary for a depressed fracture with intracranial air. Application of a pressure dressing to the fracture site (Option D) is inappropriate as it does not address the need for surgical elevation or potential dural breach. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 364, 365

questions.question: A 35 y/o man with a head injury, scalp laceration, headache, skull depression, and CT showing an intracranial hematoma and frontal sinus involvement presents to the emergency department. What is the most appropriate management?

options.A: Monitor and allow spontaneous healing with no immediate intervention.
options.B: Order a follow-up CT scan in 24 hours to reassess the extent of the injuries.
options.C: Perform operative debridement and repair the scalp, and consider craniotomy
options.D: Administer antibiotics and provide supportive care without any surgical intervention.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Perform operative debridement and repair the scalp, and consider craniotomy prevent infection. \Additionally, a craniotomy is indicated to address the depressed skull fracture and intracranial hematoma, which can create pressure on the brain and lead to serious complications. Aspect Closed Skull Fracture Open (Compound) Skull Fracture Overlying Skin Skin remains intact; brain and inner structures are not exposed. Skin is disrupted; the brain may be exposed, increasing infection risk. Treatment Typically heals on its own; monitoring for complications is key. It involves scalp repair, operative debridement, and preventing infection. Craniotomy Indications: Depression greater than cranial thickness. Intracranial hematoma. Frontal sinus involvement. Monitor and allow spontaneous healing with no immediate intervention (Option A): This option is more appropriate for closed skull fractures where the skin remains intact, and there is no exposure to the brain. Order a follow-up CT scan in 24 hours to reassess the extent of the injuries (Option B): Although follow-up imaging may be useful in some cases, it is not the immediate priority here. Administer antibiotics and provide supportive care without any surgical intervention (Option D): Antibiotics and supportive care are essential components of treatment but are not sufficient alone for an open skull fracture with associated complications like depression and hematoma.
